headline: Government Advances Controversial Voting Law Changes Amid Fierce Debates on Cost of Living and Oil Sector Liability
summary: Parliament was dominated by the first reading of a contentious Electoral Amendment Bill, which seeks to tighten enrolment deadlines and ban all prisoners from voting, sparking accusations of voter suppression from opposition parties. The legislative push was set against a backdrop of fiery Question Time exchanges where the Government defended its economic record against intense scrutiny over the ongoing cost of living crisis, public sector pay, and corporate tax breaks.

topicSummaries.topic: Electoral Amendment Bill Passes First Reading Amid Accusations of Voter Suppression
topicSummaries.content: The Government's Electoral Amendment Bill passed its first reading, initiating significant changes to New Zealand's voting laws. Key proposals include closing the electoral roll 13 days before election day, effectively ending same-day enrolment, and banning all sentenced prisoners from voting. Minister of Justice Paul Goldsmith argued the changes are necessary to ensure timelier election results, reduce administrative strain, and uphold the integrity of the system. However, the bill was met with fierce resistance from opposition parties, who labelled it a "dark day for democracy." They argued the changes would disenfranchise hundreds of thousands of voters, disproportionately affecting renters, young people, Māori, and Pasifika communities, and represent an unjustified limitation on the fundamental right to vote.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Paul Goldsmith (National)
keyExchanges.quote: We've heard lots of claims about 100,000 people being disenfranchised. I reject that absolutely. Around 110,000 enrolled or updated their enrolment details on election day last year only because they were told they could, so some people did. The message will be different this election. People will be told they need to be enrolled well before voting starts.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Dr Duncan Webb (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: Well, it's a dark day for democracy. Here in New Zealand, we have a proud tradition of extending the franchise to women before any other country in the world and of constantly making our democracy accessible to everyone, and what's this Government doing? What's Christopher Luxon doing? He is making it harder for people to vote. It's shameful—it's absolutely shameful.

topicSummaries.topic: PM Clashes with Opposition Over Cost of Living Crisis and Government Priorities
topicSummaries.content: Question Time was dominated by heated exchanges over the cost of living crisis and the Government's priorities. Leader of the Opposition Chris Hipkins challenged the Prime Minister on increasing pay for board directors by up to 80% while offering nurses and teachers a 1% pay rise, and providing tax breaks to a tobacco company. Prime Minister Christopher Luxon defended the director fee hikes as necessary for good governance of Crown entities and stated the tobacco policy was a health measure to help people quit smoking. Finance Minister Nicola Willis faced questions from Labour's Barbara Edmonds about rising demand at food banks, countering that official food price inflation has fallen significantly under the current government. The Government also highlighted its move to ban checkout surcharges on card payments as a key cost-saving measure for consumers.

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Chris Hipkins (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: Why does his Government think that in a cost of living crisis, hiking up the fees of board directors by up to 80 percent is more important than pay rises for teachers and nurses, who are being offered a paltry 1 percent pay increase—less than the rate of inflation?

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Christopher Luxon (National)
keyExchanges.quote: Well, as the member will well understand, having been a Minister for the public sector, we want to make sure that our Crown entities, which are delivering some our most critical public services, are incredibly well governed and well managed and well led... we've been advised that we need more competitive payment for those directors, which, essentially, hasn't moved in the course of over a decade.

topicSummaries.topic: Debate Erupts Over Oil and Gas Liability as Crown Minerals Bill Recommitted
topicSummaries.content: In an unusual parliamentary move, the Crown Minerals Amendment Bill was discharged from its third reading and recommitted to the committee stage to consider a new amendment paper. The debate focused on changes to the decommissioning liability regime for the oil and gas industry. Minister for Resources Shane Jones argued the amendments close a loophole where liability could be escaped through share transfers, balancing taxpayer protection with the need to reinvigorate the sector. However, the Opposition heavily criticised the changes, arguing they weaken protections for New Zealand taxpayers against clean-up costs, estimated at $2.5 billion. They also condemned the process, stating the new amendments were drafted after confidential consultations with industry stakeholders while excluding iwi and environmental groups, and grant excessive and ill-defined discretionary power to ministers.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Shane Jones (NZ First)
keyExchanges.quote: it became evident to us that someone departing through a process of a share transfer or disposal of equity may escape any liability whatsoever... this corrects that loophole which has actually existed for quite some time. The balance that we've sought to strike is to ensure that we don't provide an unnecessary level of risk to the revenue base of the Crown or at the same time we don't add to the chilling impact that has blighted this sector for quite some time.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Dr Megan Woods (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: This is not a Government that is putting New Zealand first, that is certainly for sure. What we see is a Government that is prepared to put big oil and big gas companies before the interests of the taxpayers of New Zealand, with these watered-down provisions that we are going to be seeking answers about today in these decommissioning obligations that are there.

conclusion: The day's proceedings highlighted a clear ideological divide, with the Government driving forward its legislative agenda on electoral and resource laws while defending its economic management against opposition claims that it prioritises corporate interests over everyday New Zealanders and democratic accessibility.
